question: Which human activity most relies on high-quality, nutrient-rich soil?

content.source_1: The activities to compare are: growing crops (field agriculture), managing forests for timber (forestry), offshore fishing, and assembling consumer electronics; of these, only growing crops and forestry involve plants rooting in and obtaining nutrients from soil.
content.source_2: For soil-grown annual crops, high soil quality—good structure, fertility, and water-holding capacity—strongly controls yields; poor soils commonly limit crop growth unless conditions are improved.
content.source_3: Farmers can substantially improve low-quality soils through fertilizers, lime, organic amendments, and irrigation, enabling high yields even on initially marginal soils.
content.source_4: Forest productivity depends on inherent soil properties maintained over decades; soil compaction, erosion, or nutrient depletion depress tree growth long-term, and large-scale soil amendments in forests are rarely feasible.
content.source_5: Compared to trees, many annual crops are shallow-rooted and have short growth cycles, making them especially sensitive to topsoil quality and short-term nutrient availability.
content.source_6: Hydroponic and other soilless systems produce many vegetables and herbs at commercial scale without any soil, demonstrating that crop production can, in many cases, be decoupled from soil quality.
